detailsOfAchievement: PHCP has reintroduced more than hundred captive bred hogs at three sites in Assam and continues to promote scientific management of grassland habitat. The Assam Haathi Project has helped in reduction of human elephant conflict with community based interventions in five districts of Assam through use of such chilli deterrents solar power fencing capacity building and strengthening of livelihoods in the affected communities. EBP has promoted community based ecotourism.

sourceOfFunds.departmentName: International Union For Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources IUCN
sourceOfFunds.purpose: Conservation of critically endangered Pygmy Hogs (Porcula salvania), protected under Schedule I of Wildlife (Protection) Act 1972, that was reduced to a single tiny population in Assam. Pygmy Hogs bred in captivity at Basistha Guwahati and Potasali Nameri were released in Orang National Park under a conservation breeding and reintroduction project with support and partnership of the Assam State Forest Department.

Grant was in support of Assam Haathi Project, a project for mitigation of human elephant conflict. Under the project a solar power fence and three community weaving center were planned and eventually constructed to benefit the inhabitants of three villages, particularly women.

sourceOfFunds.departmentName: International Union For Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources IUCN
sourceOfFunds.purpose: In addition to conservation breeding of critically endangered Pygmy Hogs ((Porcula salvania), the Pygmy Hog Conservation Programme continued to work towards restoration of threatened grassland habitats in some PAs of Assam. This year captive bred were reintroduced in Barnadi Wildlife Sanctuary in collaboration with the Assam State Forest Department. Hogs released in Orang National Park between 2011 and 2015 were monitored and assistance was given for scientific management of grasslands in the PA

Grant was in support of Assam Haathi Project, a project for mitigation of human elephant conflict. A solar power fence to protect villages from wild elephants was installed and three community weaving centres for women self help groups were constructed.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: We were just four months old as an organisation and we were trying to understand the grant/funding market
We were just four months old as an organisation and we were trying to understand the grant/funding market

We had applied for 80G Income Tax Exemption and did not get on time. We were busy with the central government project on skill development. Our team was too small to undertake any more responsibilities.

As soon we got the 80G Income Tax Exemption certificate, had to apply for 12A Income Tax exemption, by the time we were given to understand that the organisation has to complete three financial years before applying for CSR sponsored funds.

This was the turning period for the organisation, has the sales of revenue through projects went down by almost 90% and the faith in the system and human being got eroded. We pulled ourselves and decided to work with more vigor and determination and without any element of fear started the journey to work in the following areas: 1. Skill Development 2. Education 3. Employability

sourceOfFunds.purpose: The project “Improving Maternal and Child Health in Rural Areas of Jharkhand and Orissa, through Empowerment of Tribal Communities” was the Step 2. It was started to further test the adaptations, suitability and scalability ofparticipatory women’s group interventions into new geographies. It was particularly intended to improve the maternal and child health of tribal communities in Jharkhand and Orissa states.This project made two significant additions to the body of work done earlier.

The project aimed to improve food security for tribal communities in Gajapati and Rayagada districts of Odisha. Interventions included a combination of strategies to improve household level incomes from farm and non-farm livelihood activities, climate change adaptations and encouraging rural communities to utilize benefits of government schemes in health and nutrition.Covering a population 3000 households, the project was managed by a coordinator, 2 Cluster Facilitators and 12 Volunteers.

Ekjut conducted a baseline study to assess the prevalence of gender-based violence in 60 villages of West Signbhum (where Ekjut had already implemented its health and nutrition module under one of its earlier projects) to understand the context, current forms, acceptability and prevalence of gender-based violence amongst the communities. Based on the qualitative and quantitative findings the intervention was designed endeavouring to prevent Gender basedViolence through Community Mobilisation.

The Project aims to operationalize two state-run women shelters for women employed in unorganized sector as daily wage earners in Ranchi city of Jharkhand. The project is being supported by Indo Global Social Service Society. To achieve this aim, the project has been endeavoring towards assuring inclusive policy level changes for women’s right to shelter via strategic engagement withthe policy makers and implementers, also promoting community-led approaches in synergy with civil society

POSHAN Study started in the year 2012 in 185 villages in three districts of West Singhbhum, Saraikela-Kharswan and Keonjhar. The objectives of the study are: 1. To evaluate the impact of an intervention on underweight, stunting and wasting among children under 2 in the study areas. 2. To assess the effect of the intervention on feeding, infection control and caring practices for children under 2. The study area includes 18 clusters covering an estimated population of 114044 .

Ekjut with the support of PACS planned to reduce the welfare gap between the socially excluded population and general population. With the purpose of improving the uptake of entitlements, the project titled ‘Improving Maternal Newborn Child Health and Nutrition through Empowerment of Indigenous Communities’ was implemented in 4 blocks of 4 districts in Jharkhand - namely, Kamdara, Basia, Raidih and Chainpur.

This is our yet another project highlighting the importance of ‘evidence’ and ‘differentiation’ in research, action and advocacy. MDG 4 concerning Child Mortality and MDG 5 concerning Maternal Mortality, have internationally set goals for achievement at global scale, cascading backwards into targets at national and state levels. Though a global resolve to reduce infant and maternity is well appreciated, one should also note here the difference in ‘starting points’.......

The initiative seeks to mobilize communities around the issues of health and nutrition among mothers and children, improvement in dietary diversity, nutrition intake, feeding practices, infection control, hygiene, care giving practices and also early childhood development. The intervention adopts a two-pronged strategy: HOME VISITS PARTICIPATORY LEARNING AND ACTION:To address underlying causes of malnutrition through monthly PLA meetings with women’s groups to address issues ......

This formative study was carried out in three rural and largely tribal districts of Jharkhand and Odisha, two states of eastern India. India bears the highest burden of child mortality (nearly 30%) and morbidity globally. The under-five mortality rate was estimated at 63 per 1000 live births in 2010 and around half of children under three are thought to be stunted, with a prevalence of stunting among Scheduled Tribes exceeding 60% (WHO and UNICEF, 2012, NFHS-3, 2006).

The project aimed to improve food security for tribal communities in Gajapati and Rayagada districts of Odisha. Interventions included a combination of strategies to improve household level incomes from farm and non-farm livelihood activities, climate change adaptations and encouraging rural communities to utilize benefits of government schemes in health and nutrition.Covering a population 3000 households, the project was managed by a coordinator, 2 Cluster Facilitators and 12 Volunteers.

sourceOfFunds.departmentName: UK MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL AND PUBLIC HEALTH FOUNDATION OF INDIA
sourceOfFunds.purpose: Ekjut initiated the CARING Trial ‘Community Action Research to Improve Nutrition and Growth in rural India’. The focus of the project is to reduce stunting among children under-two, by involving community based facilitators –‘Suposhan Karyakartas’, who are modeled on a second Anganwadi worker in two rural districts of Jharkhand and Odisha. The CARING aims to assess the impact of a community-based intervention on the improvement of child growth in rural areas of eastern India.

Ekjut is working as technical resource organization for NGOs of Jharkhand – to implement Women’s groups participatory learning and action meetings on Nutrition. Two phases of training on maternal and child nutrition has been organized for coordinators of partnering organisations. A 20 meeting cycle training module has been prepared for meeting facilitators. Women’s groups PLA meetings are being facilitated in 20 villages by each NGO.

The project is being implemented in 36 intervention villages where community mobilization is being facilitated by trained ASHAs [Accredited Social Health Activist]. Ekjut as the Technical Agency helps the Government to roll out the module titled “Discussion on Maternal and Newborn Health and Nutrition through Participatory Learning and Action (PLA) Approach” across all districts of Jharkhand. Build the capacity of frontline health-workers and their supervisors to effectively deliver MNCHN.

Ekjut provides technical and handholding support to partners located in four districts and working in the area of health, nutrition, education and employment. The project seeks to address service providers like teachers and head masters of primary and middle schools; health activists (Sahiyyas) and auxiliary nurses midwives (ANMs) of health sub centers and Integrated Child Development services (ICDS) ; Self Governance bodies like, panchayat , school management committees (SMCs) and VHSNCs

To prepare City level Urban Poverty and Homeless profiles that identify various groups, understand specific client needs and appropriate response and shelter designs, including a status report on the convergence of Urban Poverty Schemes in Ranchi and Dhanbad. AND The project aims at fostering effectiveness, transparency and accountability in delivery of food and nutrition services so that the poor and marginalized sections of the society can benefit from social welfare programmes of the govt.

FLAG is an attempt to integrate PLA into the health system to encourage healthy practices during pregnancy and enhance care seeking behaviour amongst women. PLA through its women groups provides an organized problem solving framework which is used to collectively identify problems, barriers and solutions to issues around health in the community. During the year under review the project has successfully established six learning sites in six blocks namely Bundu and KhuntiSadar, Barkagaon, Latehar

detailsOfAchievement: Ekta Shakti Foundation is a not for profit organization registered as a society in New Delhi. The organization was established in 2003 with the aim to provide equal opportunities. ESF has a unique approach. We put children, especially girls and women at the center of our efforts. Our core services include Healthcare and Nutrition, specialized care for children with special needs and women empowerment. These projects focus on dignity and empowerment, inclusiveness and good health.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Ekta Shakti Foundation under Mid Day Meal scheme of the government of India have a partnership with State Government of Bihar and Delhi to provide Mid-Day meal to school Children. It provides mid-day meals to a total of approx 7.47 lakh children in approx 2025 schools in Delhi and Bihar through 14 centralized kitchens. In addition to the government partnership ESF receives donations and contributions from individuals to support Disability and Women empowerment project in Delhi.

detailsOfAchievement: Foundation for Research in Endangered Species in the Himalaya was established in the year 2004. The Himalayan region stretches in the North from Kashmir to the eastern end of Arunachal Pradesh. This region is immensely rich in natural resources and represents a wide variety of rich flora and fauna. The region inherently has unique indigenous characteristics and is home to some of the rarest species of both flora and fauna. The places in the Himalayan region like Uttarakhand have features that remain confined to those particular states only. At present the efforts of FRESH have been confined to the Central Himalayan region in the state of Uttarakhand but in future we do intend to cut across to other borders. Some background study is being conducted by FRESH in the state of Sikkim on the rare orchids in association with the people from Sikkim University. It is not only about the rare species of flora and fauna that FRESH has been concerned about but it is also about the indigenous people that we have shown great amount of respect for. The local people in the Himalayan region have great similarities in their clothing, housing, eating habits rituals and other facets of culture and yet they have a unique distinct identity. It is strange that despite the fact that they have such common geographical surroundings and still they have their own identity. FRESH has conducted alots of research regarding the lifestyle issues of such people like the Bhotias, Shaukas and some other indigenous people in the region of Uttarakhand. The daily living of the residents of the hilly regions is entwined with their earnings. FRESH realises that in the fragile ecosystems of the mountains it is preposterous to set up hotels and other huge infrastructure ventures. A lot of our endeavour has been to empower through workshops and seminars the local people in ecotourism. Home stays have been encouraged and the local residents have been also trained in housekeeping and kitchen craft. We at FRESH realise that it is not only the flora and fauna of the Himalayan region that is endangered today but it is also the culture of the region that needs to be preserved and protected. It is equally endangered. A lot of the initiative has been to undertake projects where we have gone on location and conducted video and audio recordings of some of the finest folk forms of Uttarakhand. Empowering women, the most crucial link in the life of the mountains, has been one of the significant initiatives of FRESH along with the youth of the region. A lot of the effort at FRESH is on a perfect blend of the traditional with scientific approach. Employment generation and restoring dignity for the local residents has been another endeavour of FRESH.FRESH imparts training in food processing, horticulture, ecotourism etc to the local youth.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: The decline in the popularity of any folk art tradition is a matter of serious concern. It is part of the shared heritage of community and this inevitably raises questions like what is the root cause? It isn’t as if Holi revels have stopped or that Ramlila is no longer staged. It’s just that these have become seasonal rituals and have over the years lost their unique Kumaoni/Pahari character.

The proposed project will research and document catalogue the state of Vernacular Architecture in different sites in towns and illages n Uttarakhand and analyze relevance in a remote agrarian society.

detailsOfAchievement: In an effort to build cross-cultural understanding and encourage spiritual enquiry through the first hand exploration of different faith traditions the Foundation brings together groups of young people for Inter faith dialogues. The program includes lectures, discussions and films on the rituals and history of various religions. For the school students interactive sessions are applied to energize them and show them the way to understand altruism, compassion and mindfulness. The Foundation has also organized/facilitated seminars, lectures with the participation of eminent scholars, scientists and religious leaders to understand the natural world by way of objective, quantitative measurements using the instrument of technology. The Foundation also organizes talks and discussions on gaining and sharing insights covering various topics viz. development, effects of global warming, caring for patients etc. and activities connected with Peacebuilding, Nonviolence and co-existence, ethics and education.

title: Friedicoes SECA
detailsOfAchievement: Friendicoes SECA was established in 1979 and has been serving the city of Delhi in the field of Animal Welfare for thirty seven years by managing hospitals & shelters for sick, abused and distressed animals in the city of Delhi. We run 4 ambulances to rescue sick & diseased & abandoned animals. We control the stray dog population by humane sterilization & vaccination programme run in collaboration with MCD. Main aims of the organisation: 1.Rescue of stray animals in distress, large and small, that have injured, those that are sick or have been abused or traumatised by cruel handling and abandoned pets. We respond to over 20,000 distress calls year. 2. Mobile Clinic for working Equine Welfare: A programme that has been running since 1984 provides free medical treatment to the horses and donkeys working at tonga stands, brick kilns and construction sites in and around Delhi, Faridabad, Ballabgarh, Ghaziabad Ballabgarh, Faridabad, Vrindavan, Mathura, Jewar, Tappal, Bharatpur and Agra. Treating over 5,000 working equines each year. We also build shade shelters and water troughs to give them relief and prevent dehydration during their work in the scorching sun. 3. Spay / Neuter of Stray Dogs and Cats: Friendicoes runs three Spay / Neuter units at Telangpur Kotla, (South West Delhi) Gazipur (East Delhi) and Defence Colony (South and Central Delhi) as well as a spay / neuter unit in Port Blair, Andaman and Nicobar islands. We have always supported sterilization as the humane way of controlling the stray animal population and advocated mass vaccination as a measure for controlling rabies. Currently Friendicoes performs over 1,500 spay neuters each month or 18000 per annum. 4. Lifetime Care Sanctuary for all animals: Our lifetime animal care sanctuary located in Gurgaon. Currently we have over 1,300 animals in our care, which includes cats, dogs, donkeys, mules, and horses. 5. Compassion Education & Public Awareness: We attempt to educate the public on compassion and to adopt rescued and abandoned dogs. We educate people in responsible pet ownership. 6. Sustainability: Our model for long term sustainability is a surgery and clinic with a diagnostic path lab at the Delhi city shelter which provides affordable healthcare to people from low income groups for their pets & the stray animals brought in by people who feed them and takes care of them, as well as all animals rescued by our animal ambulances. 7. School Education project: We run specific programmes called â€œMutthi Bhar Jeevanâ€ where the children bring one fistful of rice and dal to school and put it in a box. The class then donates the collected grains to Friendicoes to feed rescued animals. 8. Disaster Relief: Friendicoes SECA is also the first to rush to do relief work at sites of natural disasters. Rescuing animals in peril, providing food and veterinary care for animals affected by the 2004 Tsunami, Gujrat Earthquake, Mumbai Floods, Assam Floods, Bihar Floods, Uttarakhand Floods and the Chennai Floods.

title: Ganesa Natyalaya
detailsOfAchievement: The Ganesa Natyalaya was founded by Guru Saroja Vaidyanthan (Padma Bhushan Awardee) a renowned exponent of Bharatanatyam in 1974 for propagation of cultural education and knowledge specially in Bharatantyam one of the classical dances of India. The Natyalaya established its own school building, the land allotted by the Govt of India in south Delhi, in 1988. The Foundation Stone laid by Shri Jagmohan former Lt.Governor of Delhi and building inaugurated by the Honble Shri S.D.Sharma the former Vice President of India and since then has steadily expanded the activities. Today, the Natyalaya can proudly state that over 265 students have successfully completed their Diploma course many of whom have spread within the country and overseas and set up their own schools. The institution has produced a number of Dance Dramas on mythology, social and contemporary issues like Women Empowerment, Drugs and Aids, Enviornment, Drugs and Aids and Swachh Bharat etc. President Guru Saroja Vaidyanathan authored four art books, Science of Bharatanatyam, Carnatic Music, Bharatantyam An Indepth Study and Classical Dances of India. Natyalaya organizing annual day functions where all the students participates to show there one year course and the opportunities are given to individual and group presentations in various festivals and programms within the country and abroad to the deserving dancers. President, Guru Saroja conducts lecdems and workshops under schools, colleges and cultural organisations periodically to propagate this art form. The institution has affiliated with the Khairagarh University in Chattisgarh. The Natyalaya is recognized by the Govt. of India and its various departments. Many foreign students are joining at Natyalaya as scholarship holders under the cultural exchange programmes by ICCR. Natyalaya students presented dance recitals for Queens Baton Rely 2010, Common Wealth Games Opening Ceremony in 2010, Ruby Jubilee of Ganesa Natyalaya in 2014 and World Cultural Festival in 2016.
